The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Joshua’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
John lives in a home with mud walls, dirt floor, and iron roof in Lower Kabonyo village in Ndhiwa, Kenya with his family which includes 3 children. The community of Lower Kabonyo village collects their drinking water from Pala Centre well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making the community from Lower Kabonyo sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerrycans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Lower Kabonyo, 95 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe drinking water. John has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 2 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Sheila and John.

Lower Kabonyo community needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. John believes that the dispenser will  reduce disease such as typhoid hence a good development to Lower Kabonyo community. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that John’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

Elizabeth is 48 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Gwikonge F village in Kuria East, Kenya. Gwikonge F village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Kesaulo Mwita borehole. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Elizabeth and her community may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Elizabeth works as a business owner to earn a living, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Elizabeth and 3 other promoters in her community, Bigambe, Wisslyne, and Mary need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Elizabeth will encourage her community to treat their drinking water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Elizabeth wants to be a promoter because she believes that the dispenser will help improve the health of her community and reduce the costs they incur in treating water-borne diseases.

loans.name: La Prosperidad Group

texts.es: Este es la Nueva Alcancía Comunal “La Prosperidad”  la cual lo conforma 05 personas responsables y dinámicos. Karie de 26 años de edad es separada y tiene 03 hijos dependientes. Ella lleva más de 03 años  dedicándose  a la confección y venta de prendas de vestir. Producto a su esfuerzo ha logrado adquirir su maquina remalladora. Tiene el anhelo de incrementar el volumen de sus productos por temporada de verano. Solicitó el crédito para la compra de telas, botones, hilos y agujas. El grupo  “La Prosperidad” agradecen a los inversionistas Kiva por el crédito brindado. Karie es la primera del lado izquierdo viste chaleco negro.
texts.en: This is the New Community Bank "La Prosperidad" (The Prosperity) which is made up of 5 responsible and dynamic people. Karie, 26, is separated and has three dependent children. She has more than 3 years experience dedicating herself to making and selling clothing. As a result of her effort, she has managed to acquire her sewing machine. Her goal is to increase the volume of her products for the summer season. She requested the loan to buy fabric, buttons, thread and needles. The Prosperity group is thankful to the Kiva investors for the loan provided. Karie is the first on the left side wearing a black vest.

loans.use: to buy fabric, buttons, thread and needles.

loans.name: Asel

texts.en:
Asel is a first-year student at the American University of Central Asia, Department of Sociology. Here is her story:

“I am from Osh, in the south part of Kyrgyzstan. I moved to Bishkek, a different city, to study at AUCA.  This move has not been easy for me, as I have never lived separately from my family before. Thanks to God, we have relatives here and I live for free in their house; otherwise I wouldn’t be able to live in such an expensive city as Bishkek (compared to Osh).

I have a big family of six people. Both my parents are educated; they are trained professionals with a higher education. However, due to limited jobs in their field, they are employed in completely different areas. They used to run a small café in Osh, but we lost it after the ethnic clashes in 2010. We had hard times; my parents tried to save money somehow, but we were growing and needed much more money.

Last year I was a winner of FLEX Program and lived one year in the USA. This program gave me so much courage and belief in myself that I told myself I will try to study at the best University, volunteer, and do everything to help my little siblings, who study at school. Also, empowering other teens to stand up, speak loud, and make a change in our community. I can say thank you to the FLEX Program. 

Having the opportunity to support my education, and my family, with the KIVA loan is extremely important, and I am thankful to KIVA lenders all ever the world for believing in me and investing in my future!”

loans.use: to pay for her higher education

loans.name: Fozia

texts.en:
Fozia’s husband owns a vehicle spare parts shop where he sells spare parts for motorbikes. He sells brake shoes, brake levers, hubs, rims, mud guards, filters, chains, head lights, batteries, etc. He has been in this business for many years, and is earning a sufficient amount to afford household expenses. 

Her husband is the only single person who has to support his family and also old parents. The spare parts shop is his single source of income. He estimated his future expenses, and came to realize that he needs to grow his business to be able to easily cope with the future expenses. Therefore, Fozia has requested a Kiva loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband.

Fozia is the mother of five children; some of them are very young and fully dependent upon their parents. She spends her whole day at home and looks after her children. She hopes that her husband will be successful in his future planning, and that this loan will prove beneficial for his business. 

Fozia thanks Kiva, and its field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma is 45 years old, married, and has eight children. Three of her children are in school.

Guillerma is in the agricultural business, farming sugarcane in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

Guillerma has been farming sugarcane for five years now, and has borrowed 16 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Guillerma would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nurzhamal

texts.ru: Нуржамал 50 лет, вдова, 3 детей, они взрослые, сын работает, дочери учатся в университете, у Нуржамал средне-специальное образование, с 1991 года занимается животноводством. Она очень ответственная и трудолюбивая. В хозяйстве Нуржамал на сегодняшний день имеется: 4 коровы, 2 теленка, 24 овцы и 1 жеребенок. Так как нужно платить за обучение дочерей и помогать сыну, а доходов катастрофически не хватает, Нуржамал решила развивать ее бизнес, поэтому она обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 150,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец. Доходы от кредита Нуржамал хочет вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота, что позволит улучшить благосостояние семьи и построить дом для сына.
texts.en:
Nurzhamal is 50 and widowed with three adult children. Her son has a job and her daughters are university students. She has a specialist high school education and has been working in animal husbandry since 1991. She is very responsible and hardworking. On her farm she currently has four cows, two calves, 24 sheep and one colt.

Since she needs to pay for her daughters' education and help her son and her income isn't nearly enough to do so, Nurzhamal has decided to develop her business. Therefore she has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 150,000 KGS to purchase sheep. She wants to put profits from the loan into further increasing her head count of livestock, which will allow her to improve her family's living conditions and to build a house for her son.

loans.use: to buy additional sheep in order to increase her head count of livestock and grow her income

loans.name: Libradilla

texts.en:
Libradilla is 32 years old and married with four children. She earns a living by having a pig fattening business in the Philippines. 

Libradilla is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

She has been in pig fattening for two years, and also earns additional income from vegetable vending.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy two heifers to raise, breed, and sell at a good price so he can pay his expenses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing to start a clothing selling business.

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru:
Матлуба проживет в столице Таджикистана в городе Душанбе. Этот город по-своему красив и не повторим. Матлуба замужем за строителя. У них имеется взрослый сын. Ее сын студент ВУЗа. Матлуба гордиться своим сыном, и надеется, что он станет хорошим специалистом в своей деятельности. 
   Матлуба много лет своей жизни работает портнихой. Она получает заказы на шитье женской одежды. Таджички предпочитают шить себе платья, а не покупать. Многие девушки поле окончания школы учатся шить и принимают швейную деятельность. Матлуба не стала исключением. Она научилась шить у своей мамы, та передала весь свой опыт и мастерство своей дочке. Матлуба много лет шьет на старой машинке, которую Вы видите на фотографии. Она очень хочет купить новую современную машинку, чтобы попробовать новые функции машинки, которая дает новые возможности. Она давно хочет приобрести машинку, но нужной суммы денег она не смогла собрать. Она верит и надеется, что с Вашей помощью ей удаться купить машинку.
texts.en:
Matluba lives in Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan. It is a beautiful and unique city. She is married to a builder and they have a grown son who is a university student. She is proud of her son and hopes that he will have a successful career in his field.

Matluba has been working as a seamstress for many years. She takes orders to sew women's clothing, as Tajiks prefer to sew themselves dresses rather than buying them. Many young girls learn to sew after finishing school and start sewing businesses, and Matluba is no exception. She learned to sew from her mother, who passed all her experience and skill on to her daughter. For many years, Matluba has been sewing on the old machine that you see in the photo. She very much wants to buy a new, modern machine, so that she can use all the new features, which will help her do new things. She has wanted to buy a new machine for a long time but has not been able to save the necessary amount of money. She believes and hopes that with your help she will succeed in buying a sewing machine.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine to continue her sewing business

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 34 years old and married with nine children.

Rosemarie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, beverages, etc.  Rosemarie has borrowed and repaid 1 loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and also earns an income from gravel and sand.

Rosemarie aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma is a 59-year-old married woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.  

Guillerma has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 14,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell.

Guillerma has been in this business for eleven years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Manilyn

texts.en:
Manilyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 11,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional fish to sell to her customers for her fish vending business. Manilyn has been in this business for 5 years, and she earns more income from a general store.

Manilyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell to her customers

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina is 57 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, cigarettes, canned goods, etc..

Saturnina has borrowed and paid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years, and also earns an income from food vending.

Saturnina aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, cigarettes, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Maricris

texts.en:
Maricris is 44 years old and married with three children.  With two children in school, Maricris works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Maricris has been in this business for five years, and sells a variety of items such as snack food, canned goods, and school supplies. 

In the future, Maricris would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Marites requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Marites has been in this business for four years now.

In the future, Marites would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store
